content: Regulation is a fundamental government function, with federal agencies issuing thousands of rules annually on various topics. The costs of complying with these regulations are not included in the federal budget process. Some policymakers are interested in measuring total regulatory costs and benefits, as seen in the Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis Creation and Sunset and Review Act of 2011. The Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis Creation and Sunset and Review Act of 2011 (H.R. 214, 112th Congress) would require the newly created office to issue an annual report estimating the total costs and benefits of all existing Federal regulations. This is a response to the difficulty in measuring total regulatory costs and benefits, as determining the baseline for measurement and aggregating study results pose challenges. The estimation results were obtained using a cross-country fixed effects panel estimator with year indicator variables. The estimation output is available in Table A-1. The estimation output in Table A-1 shows that the coefficient on the World Governance Indicators regulatory quality index is very small and not significantly different from zero. The coefficient on population is also statistically insignificant, while other coefficients have expected signs and are statistically significant. The point estimate of the coefficient for regulatory quality index can be used to estimate the economic effect of shifting the United States from its 2008 regulatory quality index value to the level of Ireland in 2008. The economic effect of shifting the United States from its 2008 regulatory quality index value to the level of Ireland in 2008 is estimated to result in a $2.14 increase in per capita GDP. However, due to the imprecise nature of the point estimate, the calculated effect is also imprecise. The Irish level is imprecise, with 99.9% of the variance in the model results from differences among countries. Estimating the effects of variables that change slowly over time, such as the regulatory environment in economically advanced countries, may be challenging using panel estimation methods. Other econometric approaches focusing on specific changes in the regulatory environment may provide a better understanding of the effects of regulation on economic activity.
